bestBHT.bht: In order to maintain unity and harmony within the body, it is crucial to avoid divisions and disunion among the members. Each part of the body, though different, should have the same care and concern for one another's well-being. This means that every member should actively look out for the needs and welfare of others. Just as trouble in one organ affects the entire body, the church should understand that they are interconnected and interdependent. No member should be despised or regarded as unnecessary, for all are equally necessary in their places.

Henry Alford: 25.] that there be no disunion (see ver. 21) in the body, but that the members may have the same care (viz. that for mutual well-being) for one another.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 25. no schism—(compare :-) —no disunion; referring to the "divisions
is, in behalf of one another.
Albert Barnes: The sense here is, that the body might be united, and be one harmonious whole; that there should be no separate interests; and that all the parts should be equally necessary, and truly dependent on each other.
No member of the church, however feeble, or illiterate, or obscure, should be despised or regarded as unnecessary or valueless; that all are needful in their places.
The whole church should feel a deep interest for, and exercise a constant solicitude over, all its members.
Archibald T. Robertson: That there should be no schism... Trouble in one organ affects the whole body.
Have the same care... Paul here personifies the parts of the body as if each one is anxious for the others.
The modern knowledge of the billions of cells in the body co-working for the whole confirms Paul's argument.
John Gill: That there should be no schism in the body..... No complaint of one member against another, as useless and unnecessary; no murmuring on that account; no tumults and rioting; no rebellion and insurrection of one against another; no dissension, no division.

But that the members should have the same care one for another; that is, they are so tempered and mixed together, are in such close union with, and have such a dependence on each other, that they are necessarily obliged to take care of each other's good and welfare, because they cannot do one without another.

And so God has ordered it in the church, that persons should be so placed in it, and gifts disposed of among them in such a manner, that every man is obliged, not only to look on, and be concerned for his own things, that he takes care of himself, and performs his office, but that he looks every man on the things of others, his good and safety being involved in theirs.

bhtAttempts.bht: In order to maintain unity and harmony within the body, it is crucial to avoid divisions and disunion among the members. Each part of the body, though different, should have the same care and concern for one another's well-being. This means that every member should actively look out for the needs and welfare of others. Just as trouble in one organ affects the entire body, the church should understand that they are interconnected and interdependent. No member should be despised or regarded as unnecessary, for all are equally necessary in their places. The modern understanding of the intricate co-working of billions of cells in the body affirms the importance of Paul's argument. The church should strive for a deep interest in and constant solicitude over each of its members.

To maintain unity, the body must avoid divisions and care for one another. Trouble in one organ affects the whole body, and similarly, each part of the church has a vital role. No member should be despised or regarded as unnecessary, as all are equally important. The modern understanding of billions of cells co-working for the whole confirms Paul's argument. The church should prioritize an interest in and care for every member to maintain harmony and ensure mutual well-being.

In order to maintain unity within the body, it is crucial to avoid divisions and disunion. Trouble in one organ affects the whole body, just as trouble within the church has a ripple effect. Each member should have the same care and concern for one another, taking an active role in looking out for the needs and welfare of others. The interdependence of the body and the equal value of its members should be recognized, promoting a deep interest and constant solicitude for each member's well-being.

To maintain unity and avoid disunion, each member of the body should have the same care and concern for one another. Just as trouble in one organ affects the whole body, divisions within the church have detrimental effects. No member should be despised or regarded as unnecessary since all are equally important. The church should prioritize looking out for each other's welfare and promote a deep interest in the well-being of every member. Recognizing the interdependence of its members will foster unity and harmony within the body.

In order to maintain unity and harmony within the body, it is crucial to avoid divisions and disunion among the members. Each part of the body, though different, should have the same care and concern for one another's well-being. This means that every member should actively look out for the needs and welfare of others. Just as trouble in one organ affects the entire body, the church should understand that they are interconnected and interdependent. No member should be despised or regarded as unnecessary, for all are equally necessary in their places.
